    long long mid = l + (r - l)/2;

    long long idxcnt = mid*(mid+1)/2;

    if (idxcnt < n){

        l = mid +1;

    } else {

        r = mid;

    }

}

l -=1;

long long remainder = n - (l*(l+1)/2);

In C, we can compute it as:

long long pow_mod(int base, int exp, int mod) {

    long long result =1;

    long long b = base % mod;

    while(exp>0){

        if (exp %2 ==1) result = (result * b) % mod;

        b = (b*b) % mod;

        exp /=2;

    }

    return result;

}

So putting it all together:

The steps in C are:

Read n from input.

Compute the remainder via binary search.

Convert remainder to a string s.

Initialize m array (size 2020), set m[0] =1, others 0.

Process the reversed s as per the second program's logic.

Finally, print r.

Now, let's code this step by step.

First, the binary search part:

#include <stdio.h>
#include <string.h>

int main() {
    long long n;
    scanf("%lld", &n);

    long long l =1, r =n;
    while(l < r) {
        long long mid = l + (r - l)/2;
        long long idxcnt = mid*(mid+1)/2;
        if (idxcnt < n) {
            l = mid +1;
        } else {
            r = mid;
        }
    }
    l -=1;
    long long remainder = n - (l*(l+1)/2);

    // Now process the second part.

    char s[20];
    sprintf(s, "%lld", remainder);
    int len = strlen(s);

    int l2 =2019;
    int m[2020];
    for(int i=0; i<=l2; i++) m[i]=0;
    m[0] =1;

    int a=0, r2=0;
    int pow10 =1;

    for(int i=0; i < len; i++) {
        char e = s[len -1 -i];
        int digit = e - '0';
        a = (a + (digit * pow10) % l2) % l2;
        r2 += m[a];
        m[a]++;
        pow10 = (pow10 *10) % l2;
    }

    printf("%d\n", r2);

    return 0;
}
